title: Co-founder Wants to Pivot
description: After a brutal month of metrics, your co-founder wants to pivot the company to a totally different problem. You still believe in the original vision and see some promising early signals.

choices.text: Push to stay with the original vision, using data and a clear story to commit to 6 more months before revisiting a pivot.
Run a 4-week pivot experiment while keeping most of the current roadmap, then decide together based on the results.
Fully commit to the new direction now; speed and co-founder alignment matter more than your conviction about the old vision.

title: Your First Key Hire: Specialist or Generalist?
description: You finally have budget for one full-time hire: a senior specialist (e.g. staff-level engineer) or a scrappy generalist who can do a bit of everything.

choices.text: Hire the senior specialist to build a rock-solid product, even if you still cover many other roles yourself.
Hire the generalist who can juggle product, ops, and some sales, even if they aren't world-class at any one thing.
Delay hiring and keep doing everything yourself a bit longer to preserve runway and options.

title: Investor Pushes AI Feature
description: A key investor is pushing hard for an AI feature that fits their thesis but not what your users are actually asking for.

choices.text: Politely but firmly say no, sharing user data and why it doesn't fit your current strategy.
Fully commit to building the investor's AI feature next to keep the relationship strong and maybe unlock more capital.
Propose a limited experiment: a small AI version for a subset of users, then decide based on results.

title: First Customer Wants a Big Discount
description: Your first big potential customer loves the product but says your price is 3x too high and asks for a huge discount to be a reference.

choices.text: Hold the line on pricing, offering only a small discount for multi-year commitment and clear reference rights.
Give a deep discount to land the logo fast, treating it as a marketing expense.
Treat this as a signal to revisit your whole pricing model and positioning before deciding.

title: Underperforming Early Hire
description: An early employee is loyal and great for culture but clearly not keeping up with the role as the company grows. The rest of the team is starting to notice.

choices.text: Try to move them into a role that better fits their strengths, even if it takes extra time and effort.
Set a clear, time-boxed performance plan with specific targets and consequences.
Let them go quickly and hire someone more senior, prioritizing team performance and speed.

title: Burnout vs. Momentum
description: You've been working 80-hour weeks and the product finally has traction, but you're exhausted. The team is copying your pace.

choices.text: Keep pushing at the same pace for a few more months to squeeze every drop of momentum.
Explicitly reset expectations with the team, reduce your hours, and model a more sustainable rhythm.
Bring in help (e.g. an ops lead or coach) to offload you and keep execution strong.

title: How Honest About Runway?
description: Finances are tight and you may need to cut salaries or do layoffs in a few months if things don't improve.

choices.text: Share detailed runway numbers with the whole team and brainstorm options together, even if it creates anxiety.
Share only high-level risk and ask everyone to focus on execution while you handle the details.
Keep the situation to yourself until you have a concrete plan or decision, to avoid distracting the team.
